body: This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/btox/19)

comment_data.body:
This should probably be setting `this.nickName.value` and not creating a new `ValueNotifier<String>`? Assigning to value uses the [setter](https://dart.dev/guides/language/language-tour#getters-and-setters) magic to run some code during the assignment, in this case notifying all listeners.

This also allows both members to be final.

You could implement setters for these, so `state.nickName = 'robinlinguini';` will set the value of the ValueNotifier?

Not sure if it's too magic, but it seems to be how things are done in Flutter.

See: https://dart.dev/guides/language/language-tour#getters-and-setters

This should probably be using the `nickName` the builder notifies you of? No need to use (or even have a getter) if we do that. If we drop the `String getX()` methods from the AppState class, we also make sure that no code in the app can accidentally miss setting up a subscription and end up with stale data.

comment_data.body: Why not mark the AppState final and const the constructor?
You can use `_formKey.currentState.validate()` to run every validation function registered in the form. That way you don't need any helpers for validation anymore.
I think in general, all UI distances in Flutter are powers of two. I know e.g. the ListTile uses 16 as its default padding.
Pull these strings out into strings.dart as well?
If you change these to `TextInputAction.next`, it'll move to the next field on enter, and submit the form once you hit enter on the last form field before the button.
I had a key for my text field so I could find it in the unit tests, so these aren't needed right now.
The dynamic bits in this are really neat!
The onValidate method is what pushes the button and sets the state. We don't want to call that every keystroke. Unless I'm missing something...
